quoteTime: about six o'clock in the morning

quoteFirst: Early in the small hours it would seem that young Caddles came to the shadowy quiet of Regent's Park, stepped over the railings and lay down on a grassy slope near where the people skate in winter time, and there he slept an hour or so. And
quoteTime: about six o'clock in the morning

quoteFirst: Brown of the same Town came along with him, and they afforded me much Comfort; they told me they never saw the like, and it was God’s handy Work, and not Man’s, so taking leave of me, they wished that the God of Heaven might be my Physician, and it gave me a merry Heart and cheerful Countenance, and gave them Thanks for what Favours I had received from them, and my Pains still ceased. Abundance came both far and near all the Week to see me, and amongst the rest a Surgeon, who persuaded me to have the Bone of my right Leg taken off, to which I gave Consent. On the 25th
quoteLast: , when I arose and opened the Cloaths, I found my Legs were fallen from me, and the Pains I then suffered were not worthy to be called Pains; so I dressed it with the same Medicine I made use of before; within two Hours after came several People to visit me.
title: Devonshire Characters and Strange Events
author: Baring-Gould, S. (Sabine), 1834-1924

quoteFirst: She then had another relapse. She slept well the night before, but woke up early
quoteLast: ; she began to worry about her family, and complained of headache. About half past eight the headache became severe, there was again pain in the left side, the left hand began to tremble, and felt anaesthetic, the eyelids closed, and could not open, aphonia returned, in fact she fell into a state of mutism.
title: Nervous ills, their cause and cure
author: Sidis, Boris, 1867-1923

quoteFirst: There are no feather-beds, but the mattresses are generally stuffed with the fibres from the outside rind of the cocoa-nut, called "coir.". The usual plan is to leave the glass doors (French windows you would call them) all open, but to shut the Venetian blinds, and to have a punkah over your head going all night. At
quoteLast: all the glass doors are closed, and kept shut all day to exclude the hot air. If, however, there should be any wind, one of them is opened and a tattie hung up in its place; the tattie is a thick mat the size of the doorway, made of the sweet-scented cuscus-grass; this is kept constantly wetted on the outside.
title: A Popular Account of the Manners and Customs of India
author: Acland, Charles, 1812-1845

quoteFirst: She then had another relapse. She slept well the night before, but woke up early

quoteFirst: "_He_ can do it; hundreds o' men--thick-headed men in the ord'nary way--can do it; take a vessel out o' Falmouth here, as you might say, and hold her 'crost the Atlantic, as you might put it; whip her along for thirty days, we'll say; an' then, 'To-morrow, if the wind holds, an'
quoteLast: in',' they'll say, 'there'll be an island with a two-three palm-trees on a hill an' a spit o' sand bearing nor'-by-west.  Bring 'em in line,' they'll say, 'an' then you may fetch my shaving-water'--and all the while no more'n ordinary men, same as you and me.
title: Poison Island
author: Quiller-Couch, Arthur, 1863-1944

quoteFirst: Its hospitals and schools are justly celebrated. I went by the night boat, arriving
quoteLast: , and had engaged a guide to take a young French lady and myself to see all the main sights. Canton is a most fascinating city, and as one was carried in a chair through its narrow granite-paved streets (their average width is twelve feet, and they are eighty miles in extent), one is dazzled by the wealth of beautiful and curious things displayed on every side.
title: Chinese mettle
author: Kemp, E. G. (Emily Georgiana), 1860-1939; Sze, Sao-Ke Alfred, 1877-1958 [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteFirst: Her next rendezvous was at Porto Santo, a small island on the east coast of the island of Madeira. On July 4th,
quoteTime: about six o’clock in the morning
quoteLast: , land was signalled. This proved to be the island of Porto Santo; and she brought up about two miles off the principal town early in the afternoon, having made the voyage from Sheerness in exactly eleven days. Here the squadron was joined by the _Warrior_, _Black Prince_, and _Lapwing_ (gunboat), the _Helicon_ leaving them for Lisbon.
title: The Sea: Its Stirring Story of Adventure, Peril, & Heroism. Volume 1
author: Whymper, Frederick
